bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, March 9, 1920

div1.p: Carter offers suggestions regarding the format of the bibliography for the History of Yellow Fever and asks him if he might be able to include Gorgas in the bibliography. She also questions Frost's inclusion in the text of Henry Rose Carter's supposed acceptance of Noguchi's leptospira.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, March 9, 1920
div1.opener:
It is suggested that in case
of books of 1 vol., we retain
the abbreviation (p.). for page,
i.e. p. 470 (not 470)
Book, Bibliography,
Frost.
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
March 9, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Re your letter and enclosures of February 12th., of which at
the time I made brief and grateful acknolawledgment: Miss Brown and I have
gone over the alphabetic typed copy of the bibliography for Section 1 very
carefully and I am returning to you your ofriginal draft and a new one, in-
corporating the following changes, submitted for your approval:
(a) Heavy type (caps. are the best substitute on my typewriter)
for the author's name:
(b) Slight indentation for first mention of date of publication.
(b') Repetition of date of publication of books after name of printer (i.e.
imprint as well as on margin).
(c) In making my second copy of the bibliography for Section 1, I
have included full names of authors appearing alone (using
initials only for joint authors) with
(d) Dates of birth and death. This latter, of course, makes lit-
tle difference in Section 1, where most allusions are to
contemporaneous literature, but in other Sections of the
book, where, in some cases, MSS were not published until
200 or 300 years after they were written (e.g. Las Casas
etc.) the date of publication alone might well be mislead-
ing.
(b'') Slight indentation for
each line of title, etc.
except the 1st.

The above changes are in accordance with the procedure in the
Bibliography of Howard, KDyar and Knab (Mosquitoes of North and Central
America...v.1, p. 541 et seq. This is an excellent bibliography and we thought
it was the the one you probably had in mind in making your tentative copy.

Note that while the library cards we sent you follow the capital-
ization of the Library of Congress, your typed alphabetic copy follows the
capitalization used by Howard, Dyar and Knab (i. e. nouns etc. lower cased
in title of book or article and capitals used in giving titles of the period-
icals containing the articles referred to. Also the names of the periodicals
are incurves ( ). to differentiate between the title of the article and
that of the periodical in which it appears.

As I understand it, we have decided not to have a bibliography
for each section, but to have one bibliography for the entire book. As
soon as Mrs. Smiley finishes typing whatever MS of the book you have ready
for her, could she not type (according to the form you have decided on) the
bibliography for the entire book, arranged alphabetically? This, even if there
be no time for you to go over the library cards first to make selections,
discards etc? It would be much easier for both you and ourselves to go over
and make corrections from such an approximation of the Bibliography as it will
eventually appear when set up, than to do so from individual library cards.
Also, it is work that will almost certainly have to done at least twice any-
way and to start it as soon as Mrs. Smiley has some spare time would material-
ly hasten the time of its completion.
over.

Punctuation to be used after title of periodical
before imprint, comma or period? a period
has been used in case of books.

In Howard, Dyar & Knab comma seems to
have been used, would suggest using periods
in both cases.

L. C. does not use a period with
parenthesis.

Miss Brown and I have been, and are, proof reading the MS
you sent is. Its always a pleasure to go over any of Mrs. Smiley's work:
clear, accurate and very good to look at! Ordinarily we should have fin-
ished long since, but I have been sick and trying to straighten out some
involved personal affairs, so as you wrote that was no hurry it has been
a relief not to have to press matters under the particular circumstances.

(W.S.T.) Although I in no wise question your judgment in so doing, I am
sorry, with the data at my disposal, that you have thought fit to leave in
the text Father's acceptance of the Leptospira of Noguchi (Sec.1, p. 5, final
typed copy). It is true that Father did publicly accept the Leptospira,
“on Noguchi's say-so,” but it was always with personal reservations, which I
judge he discussed with you, as he did with me and as he mentioned at the
Jamaica meeting in 1924. Father also wrote (when bed-ridden) asking Dr.
Darling to come to see him for a further talk on the subject. Darling did
not come, although he was attending a medical meeting here at the time, and
Father was greatly disappointed. Also, as you know, Father's acceptance of
the Leptospira was never in any of themimeographed copies of Section 1, as
used by the I. H. B., although, as I told you, he did tell me, some months
before he dided, that he thought it should be included in the book. Of
course, according to Colonel “Ran” Kean, the entire Medical Corps of the
Army was always highly sceptical about the Leptospira! Strange, how many
people, from present accounts, were sceptical of it and how easy it is to
“Prophesy after the event!”

W.S.T. By the way, can't we, in some way, include Gorgas in the biblio-
graphy? His and Father's friendship was an historic one and although Father
could, and did, evaluate the whole situation as well as you do now, it would, I
think it would be a great pity to leave his name out of the book. Of course, the MS does
not go down to modern times in the historic sections (an excuse for omission)
and the only reference to Gorgas by name, which I at present recall, is of
his applying Ross' “critical number” of Anopheles to yellow fever (which, by
the way, as I remember, Father first did himself). Of course this would not
be a reference to original work, just to an application of similar work
in two fields. I do feel sure, however, t[unclear]hat you can work Gorgas into the
bibliography and hope that you will.

Of course, Jack, you're bound to know what a beautiful piece of wokrk
you're doing on the final editing of Father's MS. I have been more impressed
with it than I can tell you. I do hope to God that [unclear]there will be no more
serious interruptions to your work on it until it goes to press! Its too
late for “Te Deums” now-a-days, but, Lord! what a thankful “Nunc dimittis”
one can still say!

With much love to“the Susans” and most grateful appreciation and
affection to yourself,
